item.item: This type qualifies the status of the crop wild relative taxon.

The taxon is indigenous within the area concerned, and there is evidence that it has a history there, or circumstantial evidence of occurrence in one or more natural or semi-natural plant communities.
Assumed to be Native in the area concerned. The assumption may be made, for example, on the basis of evidence of vegetation community structure etc.
There is doubt as to whether the status of the plant in the area concerned is native, as defined above, or not. All records about the native status of the plant in the area are in doubt.

The plant is native, doubtfully native or assumed to be native in the area concerned and has become Extinct as such. The criterion of extinction is that the plant was not found (as a native) after repeated searches of known or likely areas (i.e. sites within the area covered by the record), even though the plant may be extant elsewhere.
The plant is definitely not native (as defined above) in the area concerned.

The plant has been recorded as native in the area concerned but all of those records have been disproved or discounted. A known fallacious native record must have been made, and it must be known that the plant does not occur as a native in the area to use this record.
There is no information as to whether the plant is native or not in the area concerned.
This is included so as to identify any situations that may arise which cannot be covered by the above values.
This data field does not in any way apply to the plant in this area.
This type qualifies the red list assessment geographic level.
This type qualifies the period of occurrence of the threat.

This type qualifies the uses of the crop wild relative taxon, it is an enumerated set that follows the IUCN Utilization Authority File (available from http://data.iucn.org/Themes/ssc/sis/authority.htm. Date accessed 19 March 2013): IUCN numbering is used except for descriptor states ‘unknown’ and ’other’.
Food and beverages for human consumption/ nutrition.
Food and liquids for consumption by domestic/ captive animals.
Materials administered specifically to treat or prevent a specific illness or injury. Items administered as vitamins, tonics etc., should be included under food.
Solvents, dyes, adhesives, resins, etc. whether for domestic or commercial/industrial use.
Including wood and charcoal production from wood, grasses, etc.
For weaving, sewing, rope, paper, thatch, etc.
Containers, furnishings, etc. with primarily utilitarian functions, though potentially highly decorated.
Finished goods with primarily ornamental/decorative rather than utilitarian functions.

Includes animals used as pets and for display (e.g. in zoos, circuses); plants used for re-planting for ornamental purposes, including in private gardens and public display (e.g. in botanical gardens).
Includes specimens used in or as the subject of any type of research (e.g. behavioural, medicine, propagation, disease resistance, etc.)
Includes collection and preservation of dead specimens for personal pleasure, e.g. not for research; collection of live specimens should be included under pets/display animals, horticulture.
This qualifies the type of the crop wild relative checklist.
List of all CWR found in the country, a list of names and authorities.
List of all CWR found in the country, with additional information to aid prioritization of the checklist.
Partial list of CWR found in the country that has been reduced in number from the complete CWR checklist through prioritization, a list of names and authorities.
This qualifies the criteria used to prioritise the national inventory.
This type qualifies the type of legislation in which the taxon is included.
